title: Algonquin man shares Chicago Cubs passion by writing songs about team
text:
Algonquin man shares Chicago Cubs passion by writing songs about team Longtime fan has written 12 songs about team since 2003 Published: Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015 1:15 p.m. CDT • Updated: Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015 1:58 p.m. CDT Caption (Sarah Nader- snader@shawmedia.com) Terry Carroll of Algonquin sings a song he wrote about the Cubs. Since 2003, Carroll has written a dozen or so songs about the Cubs and has many others he's working on. He writes both words and music, performs, produces, engineers and mixes each song in his home studio. Caption (Sarah Nader- snader@shawmedia.com) Terry Carroll of Algonquin poses for a portrait in his home studio. Since 2003, Carroll has written eight songs about the Cubs and has many others he's working on. He writes both words and music, performs, produces, engineers and mixes each song. Caption (Sarah Nader- snader@shawmedia.com) Terry Carroll of Algonquin pulls up a song he wrote about the Cubs on his computer at his home. By CHRIS MORDI – editorial@nwherald.com 
Just as long as the Cubs are playing Related Links 
I’ll be there and I’ll be staying 
And I swear my heart will never leave 
Yeah I’ll be there and I’ll be cheering 
Cubbie blue is what I’m wearing 
This is where my heart’s worn on my sleeve 
– the chorus from “Just As Long As The Cubs Are Playing,” written and performed by Terry Carroll of Algonquin 
Glory and pain inspired Terry Carroll to combine his love of music and songwriting with his passion for the Cubs. 
He wrote his first Cubs song, “The Cubs Are Gonna Do It,” in 2003. The Cubs had won the National League Central Division title and had racked up their first postseason series win since 1908, before losing to the Florida Marlins four games to three in the National League Championship Series. 
“That loss took us all by surprise,” said Carroll, of Algonquin. “It made the curse of the goat stand out even more. I just had to say how I was feeling, so I said it in a song.” 
(The “Curse of the Billy Goat” was placed on the Cubs in 1945 when Billy Sianis, then the owner of Billy Goat Tavern, supposedly was asked to leave the Cubs’ World Series game against the Detroit Tigers at Wrigley Field because his pet goat’s odor was bothering fans. He was said to have declared, “Them Cubs, they ain’t gonna win no more.”) 
Since that first song, Carroll has written 11 more songs about the Cubs. He writes all of the lyrics and music, plays all of the instruments and mixes everything together. Some of his songs can be found on Amazon.com under “ The Chicago Way by Terry Carroll .” 
“I love writing about the Cubs,” he said. “It’s my love, my mistress.” 
The 59-year-old’s first memory of the team came in 1968, when he saw his father watching the Cubs on television. 
Before that, he wasn’t familiar with baseball. That was the same year he first threw a baseball and played on an organized team. It also was the year he lost his father. 
“My father was very sick that year, so I was on my own to learn,” Carroll said. 
“You might say I was a bench warmer.” 
Every year after that, he played sandlot baseball, “due to the lack of cash,” he said. 
“Being from a poor background, we moved around a little bit in Carpentersville,” he said. “Everywhere we moved, I hooked up with kids who were Cubs fans. There wasn’t a [White] Sox fan in the neighborhood.” 
At the same time his love for baseball and the Cubs were growing, so was another passion – music and songwriting. 
Growing up in a family of eight children, Carroll said he was an entertainer. 
“I remember being 10 years old walking down a lane and making up songs and singing them, walking down the lane,” he said. 
Carroll was never able to figure out where the music came from. “I always had songs floating around my head, but I never thought about [songwriting],” he said. 
Then he sang for the first time into a tape recorder. 
It was 1976. “I thought, ‘Hey, that’s all right,’” he said. “That’s what keeps you going. You did it. Now you want to improve.” 
After that, he was hooked. 
“The first time you do it for yourself, and you feel great about creating it,” he said. “Then, someone says they like it.” 
That was his inspiration to start learning how to play instruments and record music. 
Carroll said sometimes the songs take as long as a month to write. “I don’t give up on them,” he said. 
He’s so inspired by the team that he tried out for a chance to perform at Wrigley Field as part of a contest to sing “Take Me Out To The Ball Game” during the seventh-inning stretch. 
He didn’t make the cut. 
“That was as close as I got [to performing at Wrigley Field],” he said. 
He might not have won, but the contest motivated him to write seven more songs about the Cubs. 
“I can’t get enough of writing,” Carroll said. 
When it comes to his inspiration, he declares 1984 as his favorite and most memorable Cubs year. 
It was the Cubs’ first postseason appearance since 1945, after a 96-win season. Pitcher Rick Sutcliffe won the Cy Young Award, Ryne Sandberg won the Most Valuable Player Award and coach Jim Frey won Manager of the Year. 
It also was the cruelest year. 
“My worst memory is watching the ball go through Bull Durham’s legs. It broke my heart a couple of times,” Carroll said. 
The Cubs eventually were defeated in the 1984 National League Championship Series by the San Diego Padres three games to two. 
Yet, like a true Cubs fan, Carroll kept looking to the future. And he still is, now more than ever, having started out the year believing strongly in the Cubs’ chances for a championship. 
“I think that the time is here,” Carroll said.
